byline.original: By JESSE McKINLEY and ABBY GOODNOUGH
byline.contributor:
Jesse McKinley reported from
Oakland, and Abby Goodnough
from Providence, R.I. Reporting
was contributed by Malia Wollan
from Oakland, Ian Lovett from
Los Angeles, Jess Bidgood from
Boston, Robbie Brown from Atlanta,
Kate Zernike from New
York, and Steven Yaccino from
Chicago.

abstract: Several cities like Atlanta and Oakland, Calif, after weeks of accepting round-the-clock protests spawned by Occupy Wall Street, have begun cracking down on demonstrations; while other bigger cities like New York and Boston have taken more tolerant view, officials are still grappling with concerns about crime and sanitation at the encampments.
snippet: After weeks of cautiously accepting the teeming, round-the-clock demonstrations spawned by Occupy Wall Street, several cities have come to the end of their patience.
lead_paragraph: After weeks of cautiously accepting the teeming, round-the-clock demonstrations spawned by Occupy Wall Street, several cities have come to the end of their patience.

headline.main: Some Cities Begin Cracking Down on ‘Occupy’ Protests
headline.print_headline: Some Cities Begin Cracking Down on ‘Occupy’ Protests
headline.seo: Oakland and Other Cities Crack Down on ‘Occupy’ Protests
